Situation1: They manage high-value transactions at the end of a shift, where mistakes could cause significant financial discrepancies.
Expectation2: Follow the instructions and guidelines provided by the volunteer coordinator
Situation2: An urgent directive from the coordinator outlines mandatory procedures that must be followed to avoid shutting down the service.
Story:
I stood behind the register, my eyes scanning the stack of high-value transactions waiting to be processed before my shift ended. Every bill, every receipt, had to be perfect—one mistake could mean a huge loss for the store, and I knew my manager was counting on me to get it right. My hands moved quickly but carefully, double-checking each entry, feeling the pressure mount as the clock ticked closer to closing time.

Just then, my phone buzzed with a message from the volunteer coordinator. The text was urgent: a new directive had come down, and every volunteer had to follow the updated procedures immediately, or the service we provided would be shut down for the day. I was supposed to be there in fifteen minutes, ready to help and strictly adhere to the new guidelines. The coordinator’s expectations were clear—no exceptions, no delays.

My mind raced. I couldn’t leave the register until every transaction was accounted for, but I also couldn’t ignore the coordinator’s instructions. The weight of both responsibilities pressed down on me, and I felt torn, caught between the demands of accuracy and duty, unable to see how I could possibly meet both expectations.
